docs.lead_paragraph: Four months ago, Valerie Millerick finally made a decision that she had been putting off for years: She began taking weekly injections of a drug called Avonex, to treat multiple sclerosis. Ms. Millerick, who is 54, had been living with the illness for about two decades, and for most of that time she did not think she was sick enough to need regular treatment.

headline.main: Experts Ask Why So Few Take Drugs for M.S.

docs.abstract: Scientists question why people with multiple sclerosis, an incurable disease, have been so slow to take new drugs--Avonex, Betaseron and Copaxone--that can keep their disease from getting worse; last fall, Multiple Sclerosis Society reported that only 18 percent of people who could benefit from drugs were taking them; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Concerned over the steep declines of the Medicaid rolls in New York, Federal officials are studying whether local governments across the state are improperly preventing the poor from signing up for health benefits under the program. The Federal Government has already been examining stringent new welfare policies in New York City that a Federal judge and advocates for the poor say have prevented many poor people from getting prompt access to Medicaid coverage.

headline.main: Inquiry Grows As Rolls Fall For Medicaid

docs.abstract: Federal officials, concerned over steep declines of Medicaid rolls in New York, are studying whether local governments across state are improperly preventing poor from signing up for health benefits under program; Federal Government has already been examining stringent new welfare policies in New York City that advocates of poor say have prevented many poor people from getting prompt access to Medicaid coverage (M)
